However this seemingly unremarkable item can be used to reshape the world itself. All it needs is a canvas. Anything can be a canvas. Paper. Furniture. People. Using the pencil, imagination and a slight modicum of talent, an artist can redraw an object into any shape that they wish. A talented artist can make something indistinguishable from the real thing, down to the look, feel and even taste. Turn a dog into a sandwich for example and it will be, well and truly, in all ways, except for the occasional bark, a sandwich.

There is one flaw. The transformations do not hold up to water. With just a slight shower, the transformation will melt and wash away into nothing, returning the item to its original form.

Make a mistake? Added an extra arm? Don't worry - with a few swipes of the eraser, any object can be easily, harmlessly erased.

But the magic doesn't end there. For this pencil doesn't just transform objects, it can transform reality itself. By tapping a transformed object with the eraser, it's previous form is erased and reality rewritten as though it has always been that way to all except the current wielder of the pencil. Turn a dog into a sandwich, tap it a couple of times, and it will be as if Fido never existed. No dog bowl. No chew toy. Only you and a delicious snack that nobody will miss.

But there's more! With just a few short sentences, reality can be yours to command. Scribble 'I want a sandwich' with the pencil and sure enough, you will desperately desire a sandwich. Write 'I will soon come into wealth' and all sorts of rich uncles will start dropping dead. 'The moon is pink and the sun is green'? Sure, if you say it is!

Please be advised that the pencil may misinterpret vague statements and that, once written, any commands are absolute, unable to be countermanded or contradicted even by further commands such as 'The moon is white again'. Only by finding the original paper upon which a reality-warping wish is written and erasing the words, can the magic be ended. Only the writer is aware of changes to reality, though should anyone view the written wish, their memories of the true reality will return.

That's about it. In all other aspects, the pencil is indeed a pencil. It can be snapped, burnt and lost quite easily, will need to be sharpened when its gets blunt and will eventually be whittled down to a useless nub with enough use. So be careful with it! Make sure it doesn't fall into the wrong hands. Goodness knows what the consequences might be!
